metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: JavaScript Function Invocation
The code inside a JavaScript function will execute when "something" invokes it.
content.html: The code inside a JavaScript function will execute when "something" invokes it.

content.text: Invoking a JavaScript Function
The code inside a function is not executed when the function is defined .
content.html: The code inside a function is not executed when the function is defined.

content.text: The code inside a function is executed when the function is invoked .
content.html: The code inside a function is executed when the function is invoked.

content.text: It is common to use the term " call a function " instead of " invoke a function ".
content.html: It is common to use the term "call a function" instead of "invoke a function".

content.text: It is also common to say "call upon a function", "start a function", or "execute a function".
content.html: It is also common to say "call upon a function", "start a function", or "execute a function".

content.text: In this tutorial, we will use invoke , because a JavaScript function can be invoked without being called.
content.html: In this tutorial, we will use invoke, because a JavaScript function can be invoked without being called.

content.text: Invoking a Function as a Function

content.code_html:
function myFunction(a, b) {
  return a * b;
}
myFunction(10, 2);           // Will return 20

content.text: The function above does not belong to any object. But in JavaScript there is always a default global object.
content.html: The function above does not belong to any object. But in JavaScript there is always a default global object.

content.text: In HTML the default global object is the HTML page itself, so the function above "belongs" to the HTML page.
content.html: In HTML the default global object is the HTML page itself, so the function above "belongs" to the HTML page.

content.text: In a browser the page object is the browser window. The function above automatically becomes a window function.
content.html: In a browser the page object is the browser window. The function above automatically becomes a window function.

content.text: Note
This is a common way to invoke a JavaScript function, but not a very good practice. Global variables, methods, or functions can easily create name conflicts and bugs in the global object.
content.html:
This is a common way to invoke a JavaScript function, but not a very good practice.
Global variables, methods, or functions can easily create name conflicts and bugs in the global object.

content.text: myFunction() and window.myFunction() is the same function:
content.html: myFunction() and window.myFunction() is the same function:

content.code_html:
function myFunction(a, b) {
  return a * b;
}
window.myFunction(10, 2);    // Will also return 20

content.text: What is this ?
In JavaScript, the this keyword refers to an object .
content.html: In JavaScript, the this keyword refers to an object.

content.text: The this keyword refers to different objects depending on how it is used:
content.html: The this keyword refers to different objects depending on how it is used:

content.text: Note
this is not a variable. It is a keyword. You cannot change the value of this .
content.html: this is not a variable. It is a keyword. You cannot change the value of this.

content.text: See Also:
The JavaScript this Tutorial
content.html: The JavaScript this Tutorial

content.text: The Global Object
When a function is called without an owner object, the value of this becomes the global object.
content.html: When a function is called without an owner object, the value of this becomes the global object.

content.text: In a web browser the global object is the browser window.
content.html: In a web browser the global object is the browser window.

content.text: This example returns the window object as the value of this :
content.html: This example returns the window object as the value of this:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // x will be the window object

syntax_highlighting.text: // x will be the window object

content.code_html:
let x = myFunction();            // x will be the window object

function myFunction() {
  return this;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // x will be the window object

content.text: Invoking a function as a global function, causes the value of this to be the global object. Using the window object as a variable can easily crash your program.
content.html:
Invoking a function as a global function, causes the value of this to be the global object.
Using the window object as a variable can easily crash your program.

content.text: Invoking a Function as a Method
In JavaScript you can define functions as object methods.
content.html: In JavaScript you can define functions as object methods.

content.text: The following example creates an object ( myObject ), with two properties ( firstName and lastName ), and a method ( fullName ):
content.html: The following example creates an object (myObject), with two properties (firstName and lastName), and a method (fullName):

content.code_html:
const myObject = {
  firstName:"John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  fullName: function () {
    return this.firstName + " " + this.lastName;
  }
}
myObject.fullName();         // Will return "John Doe"

content.text: The fullName method is a function. The function belongs to the object. myObject is the owner of the function.
content.html: The fullName method is a function. The function belongs to the object. myObject is the owner of the function.

content.text: The thing called this , is the object that "owns" the JavaScript code. In this case the value of this is myObject .
content.html: The thing called this, is the object that "owns" the JavaScript code. In this case the value of this is myObject.

content.text: Test it! Change the fullName method to return the value of this :
content.html: Test it! Change the fullName method to return the value of this:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // This will return [object Object] (the owner object)

syntax_highlighting.text: // This will return [object Object] (the owner object)

content.code_html:
const myObject = {
  firstName:"John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  fullName: function () {
    return this;
  }
}

// This will return [object Object] (the owner object)
 myObject.fullName();

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // This will return [object Object] (the owner object)

content.text: Invoking a function as an object method, causes the value of this to be the object itself.
content.html: Invoking a function as an object method, causes the value of this to be the object itself.

content.text: Invoking a Function with the Constructor
If a function invocation is preceded with the new keyword, it is a constructor invocation.
content.html: If a function invocation is preceded with the new keyword, it is a constructor invocation.

content.text: It looks like you create a new function, but since JavaScript functions are objects you actually create a new object:
content.html: It looks like you create a new function, but since JavaScript functions are objects you actually create a new object:

content.code_html:
// This is a function constructor:
function myFunction(arg1, arg2) {
  this.firstName = arg1;
  this.lastName  = arg2;
}

// This creates a new object
 const myObj = new myFunction("John", "Doe");

// This will return "John"
 myObj.firstName;

content.text: A constructor invocation creates a new object. The new object inherits the properties and methods from its constructor.
content.html: A constructor invocation creates a new object. The new object inherits the properties and methods from its constructor.

content.text: The this keyword in the constructor does not have a value. The value of this will be the new object created when the function is invoked.
content.html:
The this keyword in the constructor does not have a value.
The value of this will be the new object created when the function is invoked.
